title: Can Python displace R for Data Science? - Quora

response.answer_text: I know this is an old question. I saw it on my feed, and after reading all of the answers given, I felt I had something to add. First, and foremost, it depends on what you define as “data science.” There are places I doubt R will ever lose ground, and that is with those who do “data science” from a strictly statistical analysis point of view - which, while not considered mainstream as the definition, is at least a huge part of what we call data science today. In all three of my degrees (BSc, MMath, and PhD in statistics) R has been the tool of choice by professors and students. That includes the students who went on to be professors. Like begets like and all of that. As a matter of fact, R was my personal favourite for a while, and I had a much larger programming background as well as relevant CS courses than most of my peers. Compared to my peers specifically in the PhD program while I was there - more than all, by a large margin. There are, of course, some problems with R that Python mostly skirts or doesn’t have even remotely. First, R is not, technically, a programming language: it is an environment equipped with a programming language. To be fair, it was designed to be that way, because it was designed and written by statisticians for statisticians well before the term data science was ever used. I’m not saying that these were statisticians who were poor programmers, but they were statisticians first. I have known a couple of members of the R Core Development team (Duncan Murdoch and I had the occasional chat while I was at Western, and although I never had him teach me a class or TAed for him, I followed his work), and while I have a great deal of respect for all of them, again, statistician first, programmer second. If it weren’t for RStudio and Hadley Wickham, “regular” R wouldn’t be where it is now. And if it weren’t for Revolution Analytics (now Microsoft R), you would still be forced to deal with R as a memory hog. The thing is, this isn’t really anyone’s fault: when R was developed, there were no real data sets considered even close to the size we have now. I doubt anyone conceived such a situation was possible. And memory management is really, really, hard to change on a system like R without breaking a lot of things, which is why Revolution (and now presumably Microsoft) could charge a mint for its product. Python, on the other hand, wasn’t originally meant for data science. It is very good at certain specific things. It’s the ultimate glue language, and its idioms are enough like R’s that I felt comfortable switching. Adding easier C integration than R has and Cython (and eventually Numba… oh my) make it blazing fast for custom algorithms. And, lest we forget, Numpy, Scipy and scikit-learn for everything non-custom (although you can do a lot of custom data science algorithms by tweaking and/or extending things.) I don’t really know the history of Python nearly as well as the history of R, so I don’t know what decisions made all of the (mostly written in C) code that made all of this data science magic happen. It was there when I started with Python, and again, the similarities to R made me comfortable switching. (Note that I had been programming in various other languages for a long time previous.) But the similarity made sense in terms of analyses. R has a huge number of packages. More than I hope Python will ever have, because there’s repetition, poor quality, and wildly different syntax in a lot of them. If it weren’t for Hadley, RStudio, and lots of years of using R, I wouldn’t be using R at all these days. As it is, I use it for custom things I need to bang out if I know there’s something R has a package I trust for. There’s really no need to choose one over the other if you can use both. Especially as you can call R from Python (but heck, you can call practically any other language from Python). If I were just starting out now, and I had to choose one… it would still be tough. Especially since I have such a long history with R already. But I probably would choose Python… eventually. But why make a choice if you don’t have to?

In my opinion, it all depends on the switching cost, and this is probably not just limited to R and/or Python: 1. Are there sufficient use cases where you will be more efficient or productive when switching to a new tool? If the use cases that you have encountered are mostly taken care by your existing tool, then the cost of learning a new language, syntax, and its philosophy might not be worth it. However, if there are compelling use cases that are not available or it's hard to do efficiently using your existing tool, you might be in business. Additionally, you want to make sure that the new tool has wider coverage -- in the sense that it not only covers the new use cases, but also your existing use cases very well. 2. How much of your current work is dependent on your current tool (say R)? If your works involve mostly building prototypes that do not interact with other system, and is not part of a pipeline, then the cost of switching will be lower. On the other hand, if your pipeline/system heavily depends on the platform you are using, the code that you need to re-write is not necessarily just the job itself, but also other things that streamline everything together. 3. Is the programming paradigm for the new tool different enough that you will have a new understanding of how data analysis can be structured? To give a more concrete example -- R is essentially a functional programming language, and many of its data processing workflow follow this paradigm. It also have an object oriented spin to it, but I usually find it much harder to grasp compare than how Python approach it.  There will be times where a particular paradigm is more suitable for the analysis you are trying to do, and choosing the right tool is important.  If the new tool follows mostly the same paradigm as your existing tool, you are likely to learn it pretty quickly, but it wouldn't stretch your mind as much and give you new perspectives.

I think the tagline in the article you cited is pretty clear:"R remains popular with the PhDs of data science, but as data moves mainstream, Python is taking over."  R will always be used by the people really serious about using the most powerful thing (PhD).  Python makes data tools more available to everyone, but it just might not be optimal way to solve a problem.  Most people don't need optimal solutions, so yeah, Python will go mainstream for data analysis. Different programming languages are good at different things and that is a positive thing. Mainstream users aren't interested building an analysis system that is the most robust, fastest and most powerful.  They just want an answer to their question.  Python is a great, accessible/easy, and generally fast enough way to get that. Anyone who really needs speed for something big and ugly is always going to go to R.  Just like if I need to data mine strings I would probably go with PERL instead of Python. R will never be displaced by Python. A better question might be if Python will displace SAS or SPSS

What many do not realize is that many subject-oriented analysts have and probably will always have trouble with doing data analysis using a fairly low-level language like python. Python will surely eat R’s lunch in data sciences. But R will eat stata’s, SPSS, Excel and graphpad’s lunch (and more people do data analysis with these tools than with python). Also there are huge application areas (like bioinformatics) that are heavily reliant on R packages (like Bioconductor, which has over 1000 specialized packages and a common data model). So I think they will coexist. But be used by somewhat different people depending on discipline. RStudio has played a huge part in making R more accessible to new people and facilitating reproducible data analysis through the use of R scripting and to some extent programming. A lot of “Data Science”, understood broadly, does not require a more powerful language than R. And R is improving all the time.

Python certainly has its place in data science. R stands tall though, it won't be going anywhere anytime soon. Two languages will happily co-exist. Data Scientists would be using R for mode math-driven modeling and experiments. Engineers would be using Python for more code-driven ideas that can be made live faster.

I'm not exactly sure what "displace" means here.  If the question is, "can many data scientists do their jobs just as easily using Python as using R?" then certainly. Many of us use Python over R already.  (I barely even know R.)   If the question is "will data scientists all stop using R in favor of Python?" then I would say no. There are a lot of people who prefer to use R, and a number of specialized R packages that have no easy Python equivalent. If the question is "will data scientists use the best tool for the job?" then I hope the answer is yes.  :)

No, not likely. Python was not originally designed for statistical computing and data mining. It was designed for programmers to write programs to build websites, softwares etc. Later, because of its ease of use, Python expanded into the big data field (both Hadoop and Spark now support Python). R is a different story. It was invented for statisticians. It has many many open source data mining / statistical packages. R programmers have developed a tradition to open-source their work and contribute to the community. Lately, Microsoft developed a multi-threading version of R using MLK called Microsoft R Open. Spark community also embraced R with SparkR. As R is becoming more and more popular, I think one day it might kick out Python from the big data community if it solves its own problems such as data processing.

R and Python will both co-exist. I have seen places where both R and Python co-exist and neither can exist without the other. R is widely used in data-science for quick prototyping while Python is used to translate the same code for slightly faster running production systems. R is ideal for the case where you want to quickly write out an algorithm, test it out on like a sample from the original dataset and later use Python for real-time production systems.

As someone proficient in both, this is just a sensationalist headline with no basis in fact.  Both tools have the same memory-in-RAM limits, both are single core by default and both of those issues are solved the same way on either platform (add more RAM, HDF5, RDBMS). Additionally, to get great performance from either language, people write code in C/C++/Fortran or try to work with JIT compilers (Numba, PyPy, compiler in R). So what are we arguing about, syntax preferences? That's hardly "eating ones  lunch" IMO.

While Python is considered a more general purpose programming tool, R will continue to be the first choice for most data analysts doing the job of data analysis. R is immediately useful to performing numerous standard - and not so standard - statistical analyses, usually with good default choices for optional parameters and reasonably formatted and useful output. As you explore a new analytic method, you'll often find there's already an R package that does that (or a couple competing packages…) Python is thought of first as a programming language. R is thought of first as a data analysis environment. Each is useful in its own way.

Lets say what the Kagglers say on Python or R. Remember this analysis is demonstrative of where technology is headed, and comes from the Data Scientists globally. Kaggle 2017 Survey Results Note that in terms of actual use in a work-environment, Kaggle users using Python and R is very close (13% vs. 10% of respondents). 51% of R users recommended that beginners learn Python first 39% of R users that recommended R 72% of Python users recommended Python 19% of Python users that recommended R first. Programmers who use both R and Python at work recommend Python twice as often as they recommend R as the best language for beginners. Python is the most recommended language for beginners regardless of what language the respondent uses at work.

Just to add one additional point. For doing statistics and econometrics, I would say the answer is No for the near future we can see.   In native Python (no R-magic), it is still very difficult to even run a slightly more complicated regression or generate reader-friendly statistic test report.
